title.narrative: Innovations for investment security in land reclamation and water reservoirs

description.narrative: Activities • Selection of farmers communities • Resource assessment (local water resources, relations with regional systems, environmental impacts, impacts of climate change) • Value chain analyses • Introduction of on-farm water saving and monitoring equipment • Set-up a system for tailored irrigation advice (using monitoring data and existing meteorological tools and apps) • Modelling crop yield responses to on-farm water management for verifi cation and upscaling • Train-the-Trainers programmes • Dissemination of results to the Lebanese farmers’ community and actors in agricultural development (NGOs, ministries, WEs, etc.) • Development of handouts and guidelines on Good Agricultural Practices • Review sustainability criteria for grants / loans • Documentation / publication of results • Development of a strategy for replication and upscaling

As in all Mediterranean countries water and agriculture are inextricably connected in Lebanon. The Lebanese agricultural sector is the largest water user (60-70% of all renewable water resources), and thus faces challenges to increase its production and productivity (agricultural production per unit of inputs) with less water. The sector will need to satisfy increasing water demands from society whilst anticipating the impacts of the global climate change. In Lebanon agriculture is the major source of income and employment for rural communities, and the sector also provides job opportunities for Syrian refugees. Particularly in mountainous areas the agricultural production is at stake and many lands have been abandoned or are seriously degraded. In addition to sustain farmers and their families agricultural lands on mountain slopes are considered as cultural heritage and they also play an important role in land and water conservation, and erosion control. Investments to reclaim abandoned lands are being facilitated by the Green Plan since the nineteen sixties, and are presently supported by FAO and NGOs. In order to be successful smallholder farmers also need to innovate and increase their production levels and productivity. This project is aimed at introducing innovations in on-farm water management by smallholder farmers and farmers’ communities, and the development of tailored advisory services to increase agricultural productivity and to promote good agricultural practices.
Inhabitants of Bekaa Valley, agriculture sector and displaced persons.

title.narrative: Factsheet Strengthening Lebanese Water and Agriculture Sector component 4

description.narrative: Sensors installed in selected LARI and Green Plan plots; Irrigation advice delivered to LARI; advice deliverd to farmers
daily sensor data delivered, leading in principle to an irrigation advice (but the season has passed)

comment.narrative: 80 sensors were installed, now during the winter (frost!) they have been extracted to be installed again at the start of the season

description.narrative: The costs for use of irrigation water has gone down at average per participating farmer

title.narrative: Cost for use of irrigation water

comment.narrative: Cost of water use decreased by 10%
Goal could not be reached due to delays in equipment delivery and mismatch of project duration with crop seasons

title.narrative: Sensor pilot analysed in terms of economic benefits for farmers

description.narrative: These factors (quantity and cost of water, with the yield per unit of water) provides the economic benefits for farmers
Volume in m3; Cost in LBP; Yield per unit of water

comment.narrative: No value could be reached due to delays in equipment delivery and mismatch of project duration with crop seasons. The irrigation advice module is ready.

title.narrative: Neighbouring farmers have adopted more efficient irrigation practices

description.narrative: water saving benefits disseminated acros regional cooperatives

title.narrative: Number of farmers in the region reached

description.narrative: Farmers have been reached through the various meetings (combined with Component 5 on adapted greenhouses)

comment.narrative: 10% of farmers in the region informed
Participating lead farmers are familiar with installation, concepts and use of web-based (App supported) soil moisture sensoring. They share this knowledge in their networks
